bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, December 1, 1944

div1.p: Hench asks Cooke to identify people in a photograph taken at Camp Lazear. He includes a letter from Truby to Hench in which Truby identifies the people.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, December 1, 1944
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
1 December, 1944
Doctor Robert P. Cooke
Lexington-Rockbridge Health Department
Lexington, Virginia
My dear Doctor Cooke:
div1.p:
Some months ago, I visited Mrs. Walter Reed and her daughter
in their home in Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania, about sixty miles out-
side of Washington. They showed me many souvenirs of Doctor Reed, including
an old scrap book and some photographs. In the scrap book was a newspaper
article, cut out and pasted in the book. It included the only actual photo-
graph of the “Yellow Fever Wards” that I have ever seen. I had it photo-
graphed and am enclosing a copy. Can you identify it as the little group
of buildings across the railroad track from the main hospital at Camp
Columbia? Also, Mrs. Reed let me copy a photograph of a group of men
under a tree. I am absolutely certain that this photograph was taken at
Camp Lazear. You will notice dimly in the background on the extreme left
what I believe to be one of the tents, and behind and between figures No.
4 and 5 you will notice another tent. General Kean, to whom I sent the
photographs, was not able to recognize any of the figures and was not even
sure that it was taken at Camp Lazear; however, General Truby and I both
believe that it was taken at Camp Lazear and that figure No. 2 may well be
yourself. I am inclined to agree also with General Truby that figure No.
4 may be Mr. Kissinger. I can not recognize figure No. 7 as Walter Reed,
but General Truby thought it might be he in civilian clothes. I was a
little concerned to see the figures of the children. Was not Camp Lazear
kept rather free of strangers?

I would appreciate it if you would examine this photograph, pre-
ferably with a hand lens, and tell me if you are figure No. 2 and also tell
me to what extent you can agree with General Truby's identification. It
is his handwriting on the back of the photograph. I would appreciate it,
also, if you would return these two photographs to me at your earliest con-
venience.

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service
closer.seg:
P.S. Would you like to have any more copies of my article in Hygeia?
with the colored reproduction of the yellow fever painting? I have
quite a lot of them at home and would be delighted to send you as
many as you wish: 25, 50, even 100; as many of them as you want.
